title: Why do people type with mixed capital and lower case letters, as in I CaN cHaNgE hIm? - Quora

response.answer_text: Apparently this search on DuckDuckGo (sponsored by Quora, a search engine that advertises not tracking you “unlike Google”): wHy Do PeOpLe TyPe In AlTeRnAtInG cApItAl AnD lOwErCaSe at DuckDuckGo turned up this Urban Dictionary definition: Urban Dictionary: aLtErNaTiNg CaPs which is apparently the “texting way of being sarcastic.” So, for instance, if someone asked a question on Quora such as “Is universal basic income a good idea?” I could start an answer with “nO, iT’s SoCiAlIsM!1!1!1!1!1!” for humor value before going on to explain that, while it might be “socialism”, it might actually be called for, especially in light of COVID-19. I do not recommend asking questions entirely in this manner, because it might trip the Quora bots’ grammar alert and mark the question as “may need editing”, even if the question is why people type like this. This question does not have such a warning as of 5/13/2020. It is also possible that asking a question entirely like this could get it the warning that it “should be phrased with neutral and sincere language” if Quora’s AI does know the meaning of such typing, and perhaps righteously so, depending on the question. Also, I don’t like to do this without explaining what it means, particularly because I didn’t find out until I ran this search today what it meant! I prefer to use <sarcasm> before and </sarcasm> after if I do decide to use sarcasm in writing. Also, excessive use of alternating caps in answers could get them auto-collapsed as “needing improvement” due to the automated grammar alert I mentioned. Some users who can’t take a joke or don’t know what the alternating caps mean could also report it as poorly written. You can probably better get away with this in comments, because they are not expected to answer questions in ways that are reusable. Since I know what this kind of text means, I could let some comments in alternating caps that would otherwise be BNBR violations slide (as in not delete, downvote or report, though other people might downvote and/or report them), because I recognize the sarcastic meaning. Still, don’t assume that alternating caps are a license to insult people, however sarcastically. Researching this and writing this answer, to me, begs the idea of a “Alt+Caps Lock” keyboard shortcut which would automatically make you type in alternating caps, while the “Caps Lock” light flashes, and “SaRcAsM mOdE” showing briefly on the screen to let the user know the purpose of such text.
